Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2018 ACM International Symposium on Mobile Ad Hoc Networking and Computing (MobiHoc)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will fund student travel grants to the 2018 Mobile Ad Hoc Networking and Computing (MobiHoc) symposium, enabling meritorious students to share information and preliminary research results with leading scientists in the field. Most students attending the Conference will be working on topics related to mobility, wireless communications and mobile, personal applications. They may discover new directions for their research that can lead to new intellectual contributions. These contributions will be documented in their theses and papers. Similar opportunities of discovering new research directions will be offered by the interaction with well-established researchers in the field and by the attendance of inspiring talks.

The Mobihoc Conference is part of a series of annual conferences sponsored by ACM SIGMOBILE. It addresses the challenges in the areas of mobile computing and wireless and mobile networking. Mobihoc serves as a highly selective, premier international forum addressing networks, systems, algorithms and applications that support mobile computers and wireless networks. In addition to the regular conference program, Mobihoc 2018 will include a set of workshops, panels, research demonstrations, tutorials and a poster session that includes the ACM Student Research Competition.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ACM international conference on Mobile Ad Hoc Networking and  Computing (Mobihoc) is a high caliber forum for research on systems issues in the emerging area of mobile, wireless communication andcomputing. The research and development results reported in Mobihoc conferences span multiple disciplines, including wirelesscommunication, vehicular communications, personal area networks, adhoc networks, operating systems, distributed algorithms, dataprocessing, scheduling, sensors, and signal processing.

NSF support to Mobihoc 2018 has been key in enabling graduate students to attend the conference thus becoming part of the mobile computing research community. At Mobihoc students had the opportunity toparticipate in open research discussion and to connect with leading researchers in the field. We went through a rigorous applicationselection process with priorities including (i) Women with accepted papers (ii) Main conference presenters (iii) No more than one grant per advisor for each category (iv) Workshop papers, demos, poster  presenters. In Mobihoc 2018 we received 20 applications from all institutions and awarded 10 students (2 female and 8 male students). All awardees attended the conference. We had money leftover which was transferred to ACM Mobihoc 2019, where 4 more students were supported through this grant. Students used their grants forregistration and lodging.

It is concluded that the NSF Mobihoc 2018 Travel Grant has met the objective successfully, in which the graduate students were able to present their research to their peers and further strengthening thes students' goal in pursuing their graduate studies that may lead to career either in academic or industrial setting. The travel grant also gave greater exposure to female students, who are currently under-represented in the computer science field.
